Age.description: Older individuals are more susceptible to developing life-threatening COVID-19 and cerebrovascular disease, such as stroke. A mild but inverse correlation with age was seen with CNS inflammatory diseases, such as encephalitis, as well as taste and/or smell disorders. Increased age was also associated with comorbid cardiovascular risk factors.
titles: Age-Associated Neurological Complications of COVID-19: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.
Neurological manifestations of COVID-19: A brief review.

Gender.description: No specific gender impact factors for neurological sequelae of COVID-19 infection were mentioned in the abstracts.

Pre-existing neurological conditions.description: Patients with pre-existing neurological conditions may be at elevated risk for COVID-19-associated neurological symptoms.
titles: COVID-19 Pandemic and Neurological Disease: A Critical Review of the Existing Literature.
Neurological Aspects of SARS-CoV-2 Infection: Mechanisms and Manifestations.

Severity of COVID-19 infection.description: Neurological symptoms are more common in patients with severe infection according to their respiratory status. Individuals with severe SARS-CoV-2 infections are likely to have long-term neurological consequences.
titles: Neurological complications of coronavirus infection; a comparative review and lessons learned during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Long-Term Effects of SARS-CoV-2 in the Brain: Clinical Consequences and Molecular Mechanisms.

Pregnancy.description: COVID-19 infection during pregnancy has been found associated with an increased risk of obstetric complications that can lead to neurological acute and long-term manifestations in neonates.
titles: Are we sure that the neurological impact of COVID 19 in childhood has not been underestimated?
